articles.title: The Saga of Google's Closure Compiler
articles.description: Dan looks back at Google‚Äôs Closure Compiler, a JavaScript transpiler Google built in 2004 and used most heavily in the pre-TypeScript era to reduce the size of JavaScript files, check types, and otherwise handle common pitfalls. A neat bit of JavaScript history.
articles.author: Dan Vanderkam

articles.title: Speeding up the JavaScript Ecosystem: Polyfills Gone Rogue
articles.description: Marvin's mission to speed up popular libraries continues. First blogging on the topic last year, now he‚Äôs looking at the role polyfills play in making packages large and inefficient. There are two sides to every story, though, as this Hacker News thread found.
articles.author: Marvin Hagemeister

articles.title: One Thing Nobody Explained To You About TypeScript
articles.description: The author makes a strong case for creating a separate tsconfig.json for each environment your code runs in: ‚ÄúToday, I write about one thing about configuring TypeScript that took me years to realize. I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôre making the same mistake as I did.‚Äù
articles.author: Artem Zakharchenko

articles.title: Upgrading Frontend Dependencies with Confidence
articles.description: Writing tests for logic in our apps is easy, but how can you determine if a component isn't rendering properly? Visual regression testing. Here's a workflow based on GitHub Actions, Playwright, and Argos.
articles.author: S√©bastien Lorber

articles.title: Understanding the Modulo % Operator
articles.description: Tackles the oft misunderstood operator in Josh's visual, beginner-friendly style.
articles.author: Josh W Comeau

articles.title: ‚è± ¬†Why the Temporal API is Awesome
articles.description: It‚Äôs still a stage 3 proposal, but the Temporal API works around some of Date‚Äôs limitations without third-party libraries.
articles.author: Taro Dragan

articles.title: Drawing on Google Maps with Drawing Manager
articles.description: A particularly thorough, code-rich followup to Integrating Google Maps in React.
articles.author: Pavlo Chabanenko (Sudolabs)

articles.title: Thoughts on Svelte 5 as a 3+ Year Full-Time Svelte¬†Dev
articles.description: Thoughts that lead to the proposal of Pelte, an attempt to spark conversation rather than a real tool (so far).
articles.author: Filip Tangen

articles.title: Tesseract.js 5.0: JavaScript OCR for 100+ Languages
articles.description: A port of the C++-based Tesseract library used to extract text from images. v5.0 is a big deal as there are huge file size reductions resulting in a 50% decrease in runtime size, a similar reduction in memory use, and iOS 17 compatiblity. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Tesseract Team

articles.title: ChatGPT.js: A Library for Working with ChatGPT via the¬†DOM
articles.description: Includes a fairly extensive API that lets you interact with ChatGPT for use in Chrome extensions, Tampermonkey scripts, and so on.
articles.author: KudoAI

articles.title: Instant.dev: A New Postgres-Focused ORM for JavaScript
articles.description: Aims to introduce a more Ruby on Rails/Active Record-style experience to the increasingly rich JavaScript ORM ecosystem.
articles.author: instant‚Ä§dev

articles.title: Chardet 2.0: Character Encoding Detection Library
articles.description: It uses statistical methods to determine the most likely encoding of a supplied buffer, string, or file, from a selection of about 30.
articles.author: Dmitry Shirokov

articles.title: üëæ ¬†n64js: A Nintendo 64 Emulator in JavaScript
articles.description: There‚Äôs a Web-based version to try (if you have the right files) or just ‚ñ∂Ô∏è watch a video.
articles.author: Paul Holden

articles.title: JS Crush: Match Values That Are Equal in JS
articles.description: The author‚Äôs comment that this is ‚Äúa game that mocks JS equality quirks, the most absurd feature of the language‚Äù should put you in the right frame of mind for giving this Candy Crush-inspired casual game a go!
articles.author: Herrington Darkholme

articles.description: üê¶ TC39 met earlier today and advanced several proposals including RegExp escaping and resizable ArrayBuffers (and nixed two, including Symbol.thenable).
If possible, please take the State of HTML 2023 survey. Your answers could help determine what features browsers focus on next! And if you don't believe me, let Lea Verou convince you.
Verticalize introduces a vertical pipe-like function to JavaScript to help you chain operations together in a more visually appealing way, but.. it's certainly a matter of taste.
The Preact team has an update on Preact Signals, their take on reactive programming.
Engineers from Vercel and Cloudflare have published a draft spec for a Sockets API for non-browser runtimes. Here's why this all matters.
üì± Strada is a new library from 37signals that bridges the gap between server-rendered HTML and native controls in hybrid mobile apps. Here's how it looks in practice.
Publishing packages with npm provenance is now generally available.
Cloudflare Workers is a popular serverless platform for running JavaScript functions at the edge and it now has an all new pricing model that's certainly a lot more appealing.
Shoelace 2.9 ‚Äì Suite of framework agnostic components. Changelog.
Dependency Cruiser 14.0 ‚Äì Visualize & validate dependencies.
Ember 5.3, pnpm 8.8, and Bit 1.0.

articles.title: Take the State of HTML 2023 Survey (and Change the¬†Web)
articles.description: A new survey from the folks behind State of JavaScript and State of CSS. This is a natural companion to the other two surveys and should result in a more complete overview of the web platform as a whole. We encourage everyone to fill it out as answers submitted by October 1 will be used to inform this year's Interop 2024 proposals. Lea Verou outlines how this survey came to be and what you need to know. We'll share the results too, in due course.
articles.author: Devographics

articles.title: Cloudflare Fonts: Enhancing Web Font Privacy and Speed
articles.description: A new one-click service coming to Cloudflare users that means sites using Google Fonts will be able to load the fonts from their own domain rather than from Google and reduce the number of round trips from eight to one.
articles.author: Bullock and Woodhead (Cloudflare)

articles.title: The Path to Awesome CSS Easing with linear()
articles.description: The new CSS linear() easing function is on the horizon, expanding what we can when it comes to creating more natural-feeling animations and transitions. This post looks at what the current state of CSS easing is and demonstrates what we can expect from linear() once it lands.
articles.author: Jhey Tompkins

articles.title: Why HTTP/3 is Eating the World
articles.description: What problems HTTP/3 solves, how it performs, why it‚Äôs seen such swift adoption, and what limitations it's still working to overcome.
articles.author: Robin Marx

articles.title: The Design System Ecosystem
articles.description: This post goes deep into the weeds on a ‚Äòlayer-cake approach‚Äô to creating robust, mature design systems. Of course, the advice isn‚Äôt one size fits all, but there‚Äôs plenty of good takeaways here.
articles.author: Brad Frost

articles.title: Responsive Type Scales with Composable CSS Utilities
articles.description: With the help of calc(), clamp() and CSS vars, we can create composable, responsive, and fluid type scales that smoothly adapts to viewport and container widths.
articles.author: Tobias Ahlin Bjerrome

articles.title: 'Web Push Is Almost Usable with iOS 17'
articles.description: ‚Äúwith enough dedication and grit, you can get push notifications to show up on iOS devices, and it‚Äôs a little easier with iOS 17‚Äù
articles.author: Matt Steele

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†CSS Terminology Demystified
articles.description: A 5 minute video to help you talk more confidently about CSS terminology, such as declarations, statements, etc.
articles.author: Zoran Jambor beginner

articles.title: Your Cache Headers Could Probably be More Aggressive
articles.description: A look at what we can do to push cache performance (for some assets) even further.
articles.author: Alex MacArthur

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Accessibility Is Easy ‚Ä¶ Except for When It Isn‚Äôt
articles.description: A half-hour look at how to approach making complicated UIs accessible using standard techniques and a ‚Äúlittle more creative thinking‚Äù.
articles.author: Ian Lloyd

articles.title: ChatGPT.js: A JavaScript Library for Working with ChatGPT's¬†DOM
articles.description: Includes a fairly extensive API that lets you interact with ChatGPT for use in Chrome extensions, Tampermonkey scripts, and so on. Take note of the rather in-your-face design of this page - wow! üòÖ
articles.author: KudoAI

articles.title: Mimic.css: A CSS Animation Library of Unique Animations
articles.description: Not a new project but we can almost guarantee these are animations you haven‚Äôt seen before! Examples here, where you can try out lawn mower, candle in the wind, drop it like it‚Äôs hot, and more.
articles.author: Eric Treacy

articles.title: Repo Trends: View and Analyze Trends in GitHub Repository Issues Over Time
articles.description: A nicely designed tool that displays visual data for open issues and pull requests on a given GitHub repository.
articles.author: Steve Sanders

articles.title: Media-Card-Web-Component: A Web Component to Fetch Details on Books, Movies, Music, etc.
articles.description: This will tap into various third-party APIs for Open Library, iTunes, The Movie Database, and so on, to display media and info for the requested item. Examples here.
articles.author: Marketing Pipeline

articles.title: little-rat: A Chrome Extension to Monitor (and Optionally Block) Other Extensions' Network Calls
articles.author: Daniel Nakov

articles.title: Swup: A Flexible Page Transition Library for Server-Side Rendered Sites
articles.description: A library that benefits hugely from checking out the demos. v4.4 adds experimental ViewTransition support.
articles.author: Georgy Marchuk

articles.description: Today‚Äôs Google Doodle celebrates 25 years of the search giant.
Firefox 118 is out now and includes automated translation of web content. The general release notes are here, with the developer information here.
‚ñ∂Ô∏è A video outlining what's new in version 1.38 of web testing and automation framework Playwright.
Ben Hawkes goes deep into a significant WebP related security vulnerability that could allow out of bounds memory writes via a specially crafted HTML page. More discussion here.
